of car emissions annually, equivalent to $5.60 in benefits for every dollar that New York City spends planting trees, and a tree-lined street has over

base_text.text: To increase bus speeds in your neighborhood, pay attention to the design and use of public spaces. Here are a few ways to improve spatial equity:

solutions_list.text: Install on-street bus bulbs at bus stops
to speed up boarding and allow the bus to remain in the travel lane as it loads and unloads.
can speed up buses by
while increasing the flow of both
. Even a modest 0.5 mph improvement in bus speeds would equate to $255 million in time saved a year for bus riders.
Create universal bus access

by converting all bus routes in a district with limited bus lanes into car-free bus lanes with red asphalt and bus lane cameras. Using red paint to indicate bus lanes can reduce vehicle traffic entering the lane by
. Using bus lane cameras can increase bus speeds by as much as
Build a “bus rapid transit” line
through concurrent districts with slow bus speeds.
lines can reduce travel times by 30 percent or an average of
of time savings per mile. In New York City, this would translate to more than seven minutes in time savings on the average one-way bus trip.

by converting all bus routes into car-free bus lanes with red-painted asphalt and bus lane cameras. Using paint to indicate bus lanes can reduce vehicles entering the lane by
. Using bus lane cameras can increase bus speeds by as much as
Install car-free busways
with a focus on the slowest bus routes, the busiest commercial streets, and locations where traffic congestion is greatest. A car-free
can move as many as
more people per hour than a street for cars only. The 14h Street busway in Manhattan improved bus speed improved by as much as
and ridership by
Build “People Level of Service” streets
designed to move the maximum number of people rather than cars. A car lane can move only
per hour, whereas a two-way protected bike lane can move
per hour, a sidewalk
, a car-free bus lane
, and a busway on a car-free street
per hour in each direction. London's bus lane network uses only

4.specific_issue_units: Park and Playground Acres Per 1,000 Residents

specific_issue_description.text: Parks mitigate air pollution and flooding, reduce air and surface temperatures, and improve the mental and physical health of people who live in their proximity. One in five New Yorkers live
of a park. On average, New York City parks in low-income neighborhoods are
smaller than parks in wealthy neighborhoods, and parks in neighborhoods with more Black residents are
smaller than parks with more white residents.

base_text.text: To increase parkland in your neighborhood, pay attention to the design and use of public spaces. Here are a few ways to improve spatial equity:

solutions_list.text: Build “parking spot parklets” and “slip lane parks”
by converting parking spots into small greenspaces and closing
to create
. Living within

of a tree corresponds with lower rates of antidepressant prescriptions. The mental health benefits of open space access are so significant as to be equivalent to decreasing local unemployment rates by
Install midblock playgrounds
to create play space in districts with limited park space on dead-end and single-block streets offset from the grid. Children who grow up with the least access to greenspace have a
higher risk of psychiatric disorders. In some neighborhoods, there are fewer than five playgrounds for every
. Small and localized,
could address this inequity where it is most needed.
Install midblock playgrounds
around all parks that are four acres (one city block) or smaller in districts with limited park acreage. Larger parks provide
than smaller ones. Existing New York City parks provide
in recreational value,
in healthcare savings, and
in emissions reductions.

by replacing one parking lane on north-south streets (which are
east-west streets) in districts exposed to extreme heat with a row of street trees. Covering 40 percent of a street with a tree canopy can reduce temperatures by as much as
while increasing New York City’s tree cover by just 10 percent would prevent nearly
annually.
Build “in-transit cooling centers”
with covered waiting areas in the street outside of subway and bus stations. Awnings, expansive bus shelters, and
can provide instant shade where shade trees may take years to grow and where underground utilities may prevent tree planting. Shade structures can reduce surface temperatures by as much as
. Only
New York City bus stops are sheltered from the sun.

in districts exposed to extreme heat. Investing in
leads to declines in
and people

Expand the root space for existing older trees

base_text.text: To reduce noise pollution in your neighborhood, pay attention to the design and use of public spaces. Here are a few ways to improve spatial equity:

solutions_list.text: Build traffic calming infrastructure
to reduce traffic noise by reducing vehicle speeds. Traffic noise increases with
and traffic calming infrastructure such as
, and
can dramatically reduce vehicle speeds. Reducing vehicle speeds will also help shift trips out of cars, as people are more likely to
in neighborhoods where traffic speeds are lower than 20 mph, further reducing noise pollution as trips shift from louder to quieter modes.
Install “green soundproofing”
to absorb traffic noise by replacing a lane of parking spaces with trees and hedges. Tree leaves, branches, and bark all
to both absorb and deflect sound, in addition to creating and supporting a more pleasant soundscape of birds, insects, small animals, and plant noises, such as rustling leaves.
Create truck traffic deterrents
by using
to narrow residential streets using curb extensions, trees, bike parking, and benches to prevent or discourage truck traffic from using these streets as
. Heart-attack rates are
higher in areas with greater transportation-related noise pollution.

in New York City. As a result, over
New York households has lost a bike to theft. New Yorkers rank bike parking as the
factor in deciding whether to commute by bicycle. Low-income and non-white New Yorkers are less likely to live or work in buildings that offer

that are stolen the most often.
